Question: Is enrolment in the Medical Services Plan (MSP) mandatory?
Answer: Yes, enrolment in MSP is mandatory for all eligible residents and their dependents under the Medicare Protection Act.

Question: Who qualifies for MSP coverage?
Answer: A B.C. resident who is a Canadian citizen or lawfully admitted to Canada for permanent residence, makes their home in B.C., and is physically present in B.C. for at least six months in a calendar year.

Question: Can I keep MSP coverage if I leave B.C. temporarily?
Answer: Yes, eligible B.C. residents can be absent for vacation purposes for up to seven months in a calendar year while maintaining MSP coverage.

Question: Who is considered a dependent under MSP?
Answer: Dependents include a spouse, children, and dependent post-secondary students who are B.C. residents.

Question: What qualifies a student as a dependent for MSP coverage?
Answer: The student must be between 18 and 25 years old, in full-time attendance at a recognized post-secondary institution, and supported by a parent or guardian who is an MSP beneficiary.

Question: Can spouses and children of eligible residents apply for MSP without permanent residence?
Answer: Yes, if an application for permanent residence has been submitted to IRCC and all required fees are paid, they may be deemed residents for MSP.

Question: Are international students or temporary workers eligible for MSP?
Answer: Some holders of Study or Work Permits valid for six or more months, including Working Holiday Program participants, may be eligible.

Question: How can I check my MSP eligibility?
Answer: Contact Health Insurance BC at 1-604-683-7151 (Lower Mainland) or 1-800-663-7100 (elsewhere in B.C.).

Question: How do I apply for MSP?
Answer: You can apply online, in person, or by submitting a paper form through the B.C. Application for Health and Drug Coverage.

Question: What health programs can I apply for with the BC Application for Health and Drug Coverage?
Answer: You can apply for MSP, Fair PharmaCare, and Supplementary Benefits using one form.

Question: When should I apply for MSP if I am new to Canada?
Answer: Apply as soon as you arrive in B.C., as coverage may start three months after your arrival date. Private health insurance is recommended during the wait period.

Question: What should I do if I am moving to B.C. from another province?
Answer: Maintain coverage with your previous provinceâ€™s medical plan during the wait period, then apply for MSP once you arrive.

Question: What is the MSP coverage wait period for new residents?
Answer: It consists of the remainder of the month residency is established plus two additional months.

Question: How do I apply for MSP if my coverage is through an employer group plan?
Answer: Contact your group administrator for information on applying under a group plan.

Question: What should I do if I receive a letter to renew my B.C. Services Card?
Answer: Follow the instructions on the letter to renew your card; you do not need to submit a new MSP enrolment application.

Question: How do I complete MSP enrolment and obtain a B.C. Services Card?
Answer: Most adults 18 years and six months or older must visit an ICBC driver licensing office with ID, declare B.C. residency, and have their photo taken.

Question: Where can I book an appointment to obtain a B.C. Services Card?
Answer: You can book an appointment at an ICBC driver licensing office via icbc.com/appointment. Walk-in services are also available.

Question: What is the B.C. Services Card used for?
Answer: It provides access to provincial health care benefits, and your Personal Health Number (PHN) is printed on the card.

Question: Do children and temporary document holders need a photo B.C. Services Card?
Answer: No, they will automatically receive a Non-Photo B.C. Services Card in the mail from Health Insurance BC.

Question: Where can I find more information about the B.C. Services Card?
Answer: Visit gov.bc.ca/bcservicescard for details.

Question: How do I apply for MSP online?
Answer: Apply at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/health/health-drug-coverage/ahdc.

Question: How do I apply for MSP in person?
Answer: Visit a Service BC office; locations are listed at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/governments/organizational-structure/ministries-organizations/ministries/citizens-services/servicebc.

Question: How do I submit a paper application for MSP?
Answer: Download the form at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/health/health-drug-coverage/ahdc and submit it as instructed.

Question: What happens after I enrol in MSP?
Answer: Your applications for Supplementary Benefits and Fair PharmaCare will be processed.

Question: What is MSP (Medical Services Plan)?
Answer: MSP is the provincial insurance program in B.C. that pays for medically required services provided by physicians, surgeons, and midwives, as well as some diagnostic services.

Question: Is enrolment in MSP mandatory for B.C. residents?
Answer: Yes, all B.C. residents are required by law to enrol in MSP.

Question: What services does MSP cover?
Answer: MSP covers medically required services by physicians and midwives, hospital dental and oral surgery, diagnostic services like x-rays, and medically required eye exams for certain age groups.

Question: What dental services are covered by MSP?
Answer: MSP covers dental and oral surgery only if it is medically required to be performed in a hospital.

Question: Are wisdom tooth removals covered by MSP?
Answer: MSP only covers the surgical removal of impacted wisdom teeth if hospitalization is medically required due to extreme complexity and associated pathology.

Question: What eye care services are covered by MSP?
Answer: MSP covers medically required eye examinations for adults aged 19-64 and annual eye exams for children 0-18 and seniors 65+.

Question: What services are not covered by MSP?
Answer: MSP does not cover routine eye exams (ages 19-64), cosmetic surgery, eyeglasses, hearing aids, prescription drugs, most dental services, physiotherapy, massage therapy, and services for employment, immigration, or school requirements.

Question: What is Fair PharmaCare?
Answer: Fair PharmaCare helps pay for certain prescription drugs and medical supplies, with financial assistance based on income.

Question: How do I apply for Fair PharmaCare?
Answer: You need details from your Canada Revenue Agency notice of assessment or reassessment from two years ago.

Question: What are Supplementary Benefits?
Answer: Supplementary Benefits provide partial payment for services like acupuncture and massage therapy for those with an adjusted net income of $42,000 or less.

Question: Is there a fee to register for MSP, Fair PharmaCare, or Supplementary Benefits?
Answer: No, registration for MSP, Fair PharmaCare, and Supplementary Benefits is free for B.C. residents.

Question: What identification is needed to apply for MSP?
Answer: You must upload ID showing full legal name and legal status in Canada, such as a study permit, work permit, or visitor permit.

Question: What if my legal name is different from my ID?
Answer: You must submit a marriage certificate, divorce decree, or name change certificate showing your full legal name.

Question: What is the waiting period for MSP coverage?
Answer: New residents must wait until the balance of the month they arrive plus two months before MSP coverage begins.

Question: What should I do during the MSP waiting period?
Answer: You should get private health insurance while waiting for MSP coverage to start.

Question: How do I apply for MSP?
Answer: You can apply online, in person, or by submitting a paper application form.

Question: How do I confirm my MSP enrolment?
Answer: You can request an MSP Account Confirmation letter online.

Question: What happens after I apply for MSP and Fair PharmaCare or Supplementary Benefits?
Answer: MSP enrolment is processed first, and then separate letters are sent about Fair PharmaCare and Supplementary Benefits.

Question: What if I already have MSP and need to renew my BC Services Card?
Answer: You only need to renew your BC Services Card by following the instructions in your renewal letter.

Question: What is the BC Services Card?
Answer: It is a personal identification card that provides access to health care and contains your Personal Health Number (PHN).

Question: How do I get a BC Services Card?
Answer: Most adults must visit an ICBC driver licensing office with primary and secondary ID to have their photo taken.

Question: What is a Personal Health Number (PHN)?
Answer: A PHN is a unique lifetime identifier for health care in B.C., printed on your BC Services Card.

Question: Can I use MSP coverage outside of B.C.?
Answer: Limited MSP coverage may be available while temporarily outside B.C. More details are available on the MSP website.

Question: What is extra billing under MSP?
Answer: Extra billing is when a provider charges a patient for an MSP-covered benefit. This is not allowed unless permitted by law.

Question: How do I update my MSP account information?
Answer: You can update your MSP account online, including changes to your address, dependents, or residency status.

Question: What is the BC Services Card used for?
Answer: The BC Services Card confirms your identity and personal information and allows you to obtain insured medical and health care services if you are a resident of B.C. and enrolled in MSP. It is also used for PharmaCare prescription drug benefits.

Question: When can I start using my BC Services Card?
Answer: You can use your BC Services Card as of the date your MSP coverage begins. For those under 19 and some adults, the start date is indicated on the paper attached to the card when it is delivered.

Question: How can I replace my BC Services Card if it is lost?
Answer: Report your missing card by calling the ICBC driver licensing centre as soon as possible at (250) 978-8300 in Victoria or 1-800-950-1498 elsewhere in B.C. You can also visit an ICBC driver licensing office near you to obtain a replacement.

Question: What should I do if I need to change my name, birth date, or gender on my BC Services Card?
Answer: Call Health Insurance BC toll-free before requesting a replacement.

Question: Is there a fee to replace a BC Services Card?
Answer: No, there is no fee to obtain or replace a BC Services Card. However, if you combine it with your driverâ€™s licence, regular driverâ€™s licence renewal fees still apply.

Question: What happened to the CareCard and Gold CareCard?
Answer: The BC Services Card has replaced both the CareCard and the Gold CareCard.

Question: Where can I find more information about the BC Services Card?
Answer: Visit gov.bc.ca/bcservicescard for details on replacing your card, changing personal information, and privacy and security features.

Question: What change took place on September 1, 2019?
Answer: As the Province eliminated MSP premiums for British Columbians, an updated payment method was introduced for international students. Effective September 1, 2019, all international K-12 and post-secondary students began paying a monthly health-care coverage fee of $37.50. Post-secondary students who previously paid $37.50 per month in MSP premiums had their contributions restored to $75 per month. On January 1, 2020, with the elimination of MSP premiums, the health-care coverage fee for all international students became $75 per month.

Question: Who does the health fee apply to?
Answer: The health fee applies to all international students enrolled in B.C.â€™s Medical Services Plan with a study permit valid for six months or longer, including K-12 and post-secondary international students.

Question: When do international students have to apply for the health fee?
Answer: International students with a study permit valid for six months or longer must apply for MSP as soon as they arrive in British Columbia. After applying, they will be enrolled and invoiced for the health fee. There is a wait period before health-care coverage begins, consisting of the balance of the month residency is established plus two months. International students should carry private insurance until the wait period ends and provincial coverage begins.

Question: How do international students apply for the health fee?
Answer: International students enrolled in MSP with a study permit valid for six months or longer will be invoiced for the health fee. Information on how to apply for MSP can be found online. For multilingual support, students can contact or visit a Service BC Contact Centre.

Question: Is enrolment in the Medical Services Plan mandatory?
Answer: Yes. Enrolment in MSP is mandatory for all B.C. residents. Only adult international students who formally opt out of provincial health coverage through MSP are exempt from paying the health fee. Minors have never been able to opt out. The responsibility to enrol in MSP or formally opt out rests with the individual, and opting out should not be done without understanding the consequences.

Question: What amount is payable for the health fee?
Answer: The health fee is $37.50 per month per student from September 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019, and $75.00 per month per student from January 1, 2020, onward. From September 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019, this amount was payable in addition to any applicable MSP premium obligation for adult international students. As of January 1, 2020, MSP premiums were eliminated, but the health fee for international students remained at $75 per month for both minors and adults.

Question: If I already have provincial health coverage, do I need to re-enrol?
Answer: No. If you are already enrolled in MSP, no action is required. You will receive an invoice for the health fee in November 2019, retroactive from September 1, 2019.

Question: How will the health fee be collected?
Answer: If the health fee is payable, a monthly invoice will be issued by Revenue Services of BC. The first invoices will be sent in November 2019, with the health fee coming into effect on September 1, 2019. The invoices will be sent to the address on file with the Medical Services Plan.

Question: Is there any financial assistance for the health fee?
Answer: All international students are required to pay the health fee regardless of income unless they have formally opted out of provincial health coverage. Only adults can opt out of MSP, and if they do, they must secure private health-care insurance, or they will be liable for all healthcare costs in B.C.

Question: If an international student fails to pay the fee, will they be able to access health-care services?
Answer: Emergency healthcare services will not be denied, but private physicians and clinics may deny services if payment has not been pre-approved. If a student does not have provincial health coverage or private insurance, they will be liable for the costs of health-care services received.

Question: What date will the health fee start for international students newly arriving in B.C.?
Answer: The health fee will start on the first day of the month when MSP coverage begins. Once MSP premiums are eliminated on January 1, 2020, international students will continue to receive monthly invoices for the health fee. For questions about the start date of MSP coverage, contact Health Insurance BC.

Question: If an international student leaves B.C. permanently, when will the health fee end?
Answer: The health fee ends when MSP coverage ends. If moving within Canada, coverage is provided for the balance of the month the student leaves B.C., plus two consecutive months. If moving outside Canada, coverage is provided for the balance of the month the student leaves the province. Any outstanding amounts will remain payable.

Question: If an international student leaves B.C. temporarily, do they need to continue paying the health fee?
Answer: Yes, MSP coverage cannot be suspended if an international student leaves the province temporarily unless they no longer qualify for MSP coverage.

Question: If a post-secondary international student has a dependent who is not a student, does the adult dependent also pay the health fee?
Answer: No, the health fee only applies to international students enrolled in MSP with a valid study permit. Family members with a work permit but not a study permit are not charged the fee, but those with both a work permit and a study permit will be charged the health fee.

Question: How is the new health fee different from the current coverage under B.C.'s Medical Services Plan (MSP)?
Answer: The health fee ensures international students continue to contribute to and benefit from B.C. health-care coverage as MSP premiums are eliminated. B.C. Medical Services Plan coverage is not changing.

Question: What role do educational institutions have in the implementation of the new health fee for international students?
Answer: Educational institutions do not need to collect the health fee for the Government of British Columbia. If a school wants to pay the fee on behalf of students, they must be set up as an MSP group plan administrator. Group invoices are sent monthly by Revenue Services of British Columbia to the administrator or to the individual at the address on file with MSP.

Question: If an international student completes their studies before the end of their study permit, how do they update their information with MSP?
Answer: The student can provide proof to Health Insurance BC that their study permit has ended, which can be an official letter from Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada, a stamp in the passport, or a letter from their school with the date they completed or withdrew from studies. If the student is issued a new immigration document, a copy must be provided to Health Insurance BC; otherwise, MSP coverage will be cancelled.

Question: If my child is studying in B.C. with a visitorâ€™s permit, will they be charged the health fee?
Answer: Only individuals enrolled in MSP with a study permit will be charged the health fee. Individuals on a visitorâ€™s permit are generally not eligible for MSP enrollment.

Question: If an individual arrives in Canada under a CUAET study permit, do they have to pay the health fee?
Answer: Individuals with a CUAET study permit enrolled in MSP are not required to pay the health fee for the period of March 1, 2022, onward. Subsequent study permits without CUAET notations are subject to the health fee. If billed for the health fee during the CUAET period, the Ministry of Finance will contact the individual for a refund.

Question: Why am I receiving a retroactive health fee invoice for $75.00 for MSP coverage between June 2020 and April 2021?
Answer: The health fee is charged for each month a student is eligible for MSP coverage. Due to an error, you were not invoiced for your final month of coverage. For questions about MSP coverage, contact HIBC. For payment inquiries, contact Revenue Services of BC. If your school paid the fee on your behalf during this period, submit the invoice to your school.
